heading: 4. Protocol Specification -> 4.1. Elements of Procedure -> 4.1.4. The GetResponse-PDU
sentence: In the ASN.1 language, the GetResponse-PDU is defined as [2] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE containing request-id RequestID, error-status ErrorStatus, error-index ErrorIndex, and variable-bindings VarBindList.
enhanced_sentence: The GetResponse-PDU is generated by an SNMP agent in response to receiving a GetRequest-PDU, GetNextRequest-PDU, or SetRequest-PDU from an SNMP manager. This PDU uses ASN.1 encoding defined as [2] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE containing four mandatory fields: request-id (to correlate with the original request), error-status (indicating success or failure), error-index (identifying which variable binding caused an error), and variable-bindings (containing the requested management information). Upon generation, the agent sends this PDU back to the requesting manager, where the receiving protocol entity extracts and presents the response contents to the SNMP application entity for processing. The GetResponse-PDU structure is identical to the request PDUs except for the PDU type identifier [2].

This PDU has the specific ASN.1 structure: Trap-PDU ::= [4] IMPLICIT SEQUENCE { enterprise OBJECT IDENTIFIER, agent-addr NetworkAddress, generic-trap INTEGER { coldStart(0), warmStart(1), linkDown(2), linkUp(3), authenticationFailure(4), egpNeighborLoss(5), enterpriseSpecific(6) }, specific-trap INTEGER, time-stamp TimeTicks, variable-bindings VarBindList }.

This rule applies when an SNMP agent detects a significant event that requires notification. The protocol entity generates the Trap-PDU only upon explicit request from the SNMP application entity, which occurs when predefined event conditions are met. The expected outcome is the transmission of an unsolicited notification containing event details to designated management stations.

Prerequisites include: the agent must have detected a trigger event, the SNMP application entity must request trap generation, and the agent must have valid destination addresses for trap delivery (though address selection is implementation-specific).
